page.title: 15THE WAINSTONES
page.content: The great stone outcrops and pillars at the Western end of Hasty Bank are known as The Wainstones. They overlook Great Broughton, two miles to the North and stand like sentries over Garfitt Gap. Deeply fissured, they provide a favourite training ground for local climbers, being high enough to need roped ascent and difficult enough to warrant the use of advanced techniques. Throughout the year parties of such enthusiasts arrive at weekends with their hard hats and coils of rope, wearing boots and breeches. However it is not necessary to go to these lengths to admire the view from the stones as a footpath makes its way between them to the top of the main mass. The Wainstones give their name to a hotel and restaurant in the village below, and can be seen by looking S along the High Street.
